column15: 1.3 Common System Data Set
column16: Other than common clinical data set and common financial data set, there should be another section talking about common system data set, such as terminology data. Use case: exports all ValueSet from a terminology server.
column17: Request for common system data set like terminology data in addition to common clinical data set
column21: The two use cases listed are examples, not a full enumeration. We should add a section called 1.3 ("Additional use Cases") with a brief mention of other use cases including this one.

column14: _since (FHIR instant type, optional)
column15: _since (FHIR dateTime type, optional)
column16: According to the definition of instant: "An instant in time in the format YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss.sss+zz:zz (e.g. 2015-02-07T13:28:17.239+02:00 or 2017-01-01T00:00:00Z). The time SHALL specified at least to the second and SHALL include a time zone." I cannot say start from 2018-01-01 but have to say 2018-01-01T00:00:00-05:00. This is a overkill and service client may not want to specify time zone.
column17: Requesting dateTime instead of instant type for _since parameter
column21: Dont fix. The _since parameter is aligned with the default FHIR spec (https://www.hl7.org/fhir/http.html) where _since requires an instant. Furthermore this may not be feasible if we harmonize with $everything? Using _since as an instant everywhere else and as a datetime here will be confusing. We should address this for FHIR in general, not within the IG

column14: Only resources of the specified resource types(s) SHOULD be included in the response.
column15: Only resources of the specified resource types(s) SHALL be included in the response.
column16: Why is "SHOULD"? Is there any use case the server could ignore _type parameter?
column17: Reqest to require _type parameter
column21: J/D: Some servers might not support _type at all, or might be serving pre-generated files.

column14: Even if some of the requested resources cannot successfully be exported, the overall export operation MAY still succeed.
column16: In such case, should server return 202 or 5xx?
column17: Rreturn status codes for incomplete successful exports

column14: OUT
column15: IN
column16: _outputFormat and _type are input parameters for this operation. Same applies to OperationDefinition: patient-export and group-export
column17: Incorrect input (IN) parameters are labeled as output (OUT)
column21: Will fix. These are input parameters

column14: URL: [base]/$$export
column15: URL: [base]/$export
column16: Why are there two $ signs? Same applies to OperationDefinition: patient-export and group-export
column17: Typo where URL: [base]/$$export should be URL: [base]/$export
column21: Duplicate of 113.

column16: Can the three operations be merged into one with three different URLs. It is not good practice to have the same text copied three times. One example is valueset-expand operation: http://build.fhir.org/valueset-operation-expand.html
column17: Merge the three Operations into one with different urls
column21: J/D: We are following the established pattern from https://www.hl7.org/fhir/operation-group-everything.html and https://www.hl7.org/fhir/operation-patient-everything.html

column16: In the "Backend Service authroziation" diagram, the "App" should be "Client" .
column17: In the "Backend Service authroziation" diagram, the "App" should be "Client" .
column21: Will fix!

column14: using JSON Web Algorithm (JWA) header parameter values RS384 and ES384 as defined in RFC7518
column16: Why use RS384 not RS256 which is recommended by RFC-7518?
column17: Why use RS384 not RS256 which is recommended by RFC-7518?
column21: We chose ES384 and RS384 wanted to align with the set of algorithms recommended by CDS Hooks 1.0.

column14:
These specifications are designed to support sharing any data that can be represented in FHIR. This means they should be useful for such diverse systems as:
•“Native” FHIR servers that store FHIR resources directly
•EHR systems and population health tools implementing FHIR as an interoperability layer
•Financial systems implementing FHIR as an interoperability layer
column15:
These specifications are designed to support sharing any data that can be represented in FHIR. This means they should be useful for such diverse systems as:
•“Native” FHIR servers that store FHIR resources directly
•EHR systems and population health tools implementing FHIR as an interoperability layer
•Financial systems implementing FHIR as an interoperability layer
•Public health surveillance activities at the local, or State level to support surveillance activities based on defined populations of patients
column16:
Proposal to add a use case to support public health surveillance.
Public health is interested in the Bulk Data API to support surveillance studies that do not require real-time exchange of data.  This comment proposes adding a use case to support public health surveillance to the list.
column17: Public health surveillance studies that do not require real-time exchange of data. We suggest supporting public health surveillance as a use case.
column21: The two use cases listed are examples, not a full enumeration. We should add a section called 1.3 ("Additional use Cases") with a brief mention of other use cases including this one.

column16: While the filter parameter is experimental, it seems to be at the inception stage - too preliminary for inclusion in an IG.
column17: Suggest discussions with vendors trying to implement this feature and narrowing this down to what is viable prior to inclusion in IG.
column21: Duplicate of #102. Agreed -- we should defer _typeFilter to a future release.

column14: It also includes recommendations regarding the FHIR resources that might be exposed throuh the export interface.
column15: It also includes recommendations regarding the FHIR resources that might be exposed through the export interface.
column16: Through mispelled as throuh
column17: Through mispelled as throuh
column21: Will fix.

column14: Management of FHIR groups within the clinical system; the bulk data operation may include a valid group id, but this guide does not specify how FHIR Group resources are created and maintained within a system
column15: Management of FHIR groups; the bulk data operation may include a valid group id, but this guide does not specify how FHIR Group resources are created and maintained within a system
column16: It's an error to suggest that only clinical systems can be bulk servers or have a need to manage FHIR groups.
column17: Remove "clinical system" in favor of more accurate term describing fhir bulk server system
column21: Agreed -- will apply the proposed wording.

column14: Implementers are encouraged to implement OAuth 2.0 access management in accordance with the SMART Backend Services: Authorization Guide. Implementations MAY include non-RESTful services that use authorization schemes other than OAuth 2.0, such as mutual-TLS or signed URLs.
column15: Implementers SHALL implement OAuth 2.0 access management in accordance with the SMART Backend Services: Authorization Guide. For the File Request exchange, implementations MAY include non-RESTful services that use authorization schemes other than OAuth 2.0, such as mutual-TLS or signed URLs.
column16: This complete optionality of OAuth2 client credentials significantly weakens the likelihood that different implementations will be compatible.  The best case is that the kick-off, status and delete requests SHALL require an OAuth2 access_token and the the File request SHALL use an access_token per the requiresAccessToken property. At minimum, the kick-off, status and delete requests SHOULD use an OAuth2 access token.  This language was taken from the formal security review (section 4.5).
column17: Optionality of security layer weakens interoperability
column21: It's true that optionality here weakens interoperability, but there are also diverse security frameworks that could apply. Propose not changing.

column14: Healthcare organizations are becoming increasingly aware of server vulnerabilities and the imperative to protect PHI
column15: Healthcare organizations have an imperative to protect PHI
column16: The healthcare organizations that I work with are extremely aware of their imperative to protect PHI and the risks associated with both cloud and data-center environments. I find this sentence, especially use of the duplicative "becomingly increasingly" phrase to be an inaccurate slur against the many CISOs and healthcare security  IT folks working everyday to keep PHI safe. Especially considering that this sentence is simply intended to add color and does not otherwise contribute to the IG, I think you should reword it.
column17: Healthcare orgs are already aware of their responsibility to protect PHI. Suggesting otherwise is silly.
column21: Agreed -- will apply the proposed wording.

column14: This FHIR Operation initiates the asynchronous process of a client’s request for the generation of as set of data to which the client is authorized
column15: This FHIR Operation initiates the asynchronous process of a client’s request for the generation of a set of data to which the client is authorized
column16: Typo - "as" should be "a"
column17: Typo - "as" should be "a"
column21: Will fix.

column16: In hindsight, it seems questionable that the bulk data api doesn't support downloading data for a single Patient. This is a reasonable gap because in almost all cases, a single patient's record isn't large enough to warrant the async gymnastics of the bulk data api. However, it would be an improvement to the spec to call this out and to point the reader to the appropriate mechanism for downloading a single patient's data -- especially in a patient-mediated access scenario.
column17: Explain why [fhir base]/Patient[id]/$export doesn't exist
column21: We should add this functionality if we reconcile $export with $everything, to prevent proliferation of overlapping operations.

column14: Specifies the format of the optional OperationOutcome response to the kick-off request. Currently, only application/fhir+json is supported.
column16: The mime type of "application/fhir+json" is not formatted as code; unlike the other references to mime types in the IG.
column17: Format mime types consistently
column21: Block vote. Will fix

column14: Content-Location header with an absolute URI for subsequent status requests
column15: Content-Location header with an absolute URI for subsequent status requests
column16: Wouldn't it be more accurate for the content of the Content-Location header to be described as a URL, instead of a URI? Or what am I missing?
column17: Super-nitpicky: Content-Location is a URL, and not just a URI, right?
column21: Block vote. Will fix

column14: All exchanges described herein between the client and the FHIR server SHALL be secured using TLS V1.2.
column15: All exchanges described herein between the client and the FHIR server SHALL be secured using TLS V1.2 or greater.
column16: Given that TLS 1.3 is already available in openSSL and other libraries, why would we want to restrict backend services to 1.2?
column17: Why require TLS 1.2 and disallow 1.3?
column21: Duplicate of #28.

column4: Presenting an Access Token to FHIR API
column14: [where is replaced with the actual token value]
column15: access token should be included above, this [where is.. ] clause should not be included
column16: The example access token in this section is missing and the text in brackets describing it is incomplete. The example under "Example Request" is sufficient to illustrate the Authorization header and there needn't be a second example.
column17: Missing example access_token.
column21:
Block vote. Formatting issue with "{" characters in jekyll. Should read:

     Authorization: Bearer {{access_token}}  

And should read:

     [where {{access_token}} is replaced with the actual token value]

column14: "This FHIR Operation initiates the asynchronous process of a client’s request for the generation of as set of data to which the client is authorized – whether that be all patients, a subset (defined group) of patients, or all available data contained in a FHIR server."
column16: First sentence says: "This FHIR Operation initiates the asynchronous process of a client’s request for the generation of as set of data to which the client is authorized – whether that be all patients, a subset (defined group) of patients, or all available data contained in a FHIR server." I'm pretty sure that is supposed to say "of a set of data"
column17: "a set of data"
column21: Will fix

column16: There is no description of the "All Patients" endpoint. Is that intended?
column17: Should there be a description of the all patients endpoint?
column21: We should add "FHIR Operation to obtain data on all patients available." as a description.

column16: Do we really need to point out that _since was previously named "start"? It's been that way for a long time now.
column17: Don't give history of _since naming.
column21: Agreed. Will remove historical information from section 5.1.5

column16:
Section 4 says: "The client SHALL be capable of generating a JSON Web Signature in accordance with RFC7515, using JSON Web Algorithm (JWA) header parameter values RS384 and ES384 as defined in RFC7518." But then the very next sentence says: "The FHIR authorization server SHALL be capable of validating such signatures. Over time, we expect recommended algorithms to evolve, so while this specification recommends algorithms for interoperability, it does not mandate the use of any specific algorithm." 
The first part seems to require using RS384 or ES384 but then the second part contradicts that by saying no particular algorithm is mandated. Which is it?
column17: Are JWS Algo's mandated or not?
column21:
The intent was to establish a baseline of two signature types while allowing the set to grow over time. In practical use, we mandate support for but not "use of" any specific algorithm.

To clarify this intent, we should say: 

* "The FHIR authorization server SHALL be capable of validating at least one of these two signature types", rather than "validating such signatures".

* "This specification requires support of these algorithms for interoperability" ratther than "recommends".

column16: The requirement states you must secure using TLS 1.2, but I think we'd want TLS 1.2, 1.3, or whatever comes after that. I'd suggest this be changed such that we must support TLS 1.2 and optionally higher TLS versions while rejecting TLS 1.1 or lower.
column17: Allow TLS 1.3 in addition to 1.2
column21: Agreed -- we should allow for TLS 1.2 or greater.

column16: Implementers should be required to support the use of OAuth 2.0 for authorization, not just encouraged. It’d give a guarantee of one mechanism being in use everywhere. We have no issue with the use of ancillary authorization schemes at the implementer’s discretion
column17: OAuth 2.0 should be required.
column21: Duplicate of #16.

column16: I think some guidance on the Expires time for the complete status might be beneficial. Is there a minimum amount of time the files must be persisted? Can a client, at kick-off time, request a particular duration, and the FHIR server have the option to reject a particular duration if it will not conform to some sort of retention policy? This may be an unfounded concern, but I would want to have some sort of guarantee as to how long the files would be available so that there is sufficient time to acquire them - perhaps the minimum could be based on total file size and some assumed connection bandwidth.
column17: Provide more guidance on Expires.
column21:
These are really good suggestions; we should explore these in future work, but we don't have experience with over-the-wire negotiation and it seems hard to come up with specific recommendations for bandwidth expectations, etc. 

In the meantime, we can recommend that servers SHOULD not delete files from a bulk data response that a client is actively in the process of downloading, regardless of the pre-specified Expires time.

column4: Backend Services Authorization> Registering a SMART Backend Service (communicating public keys):
column14: the client SHALL obtain a client-to-client digital certificate
column16: It's unclear to me why a certificate is needed. I would think that we need a public key in some transportable format. Having a program generate a certificate is one method to get a key pair, but it's not the only way; plus, the key will have to be converted to a JWK format anyway. I think this should be that a client shall obtain an asymmetric key pair and shall register the public key with the server's authorization service.
column17: Why is a certificate required?
column21: We should change "obtain a client-to-client digital certificate" to say "generate or obtain an asymmetric keypair".

column4: Backend Services Authorization> Registering a SMART Backend Service (communicating public keys):
column14: When provided, this URL SHALL match the jku header parameter in the client’s Authorization JWT
column16: I think what we mean here is that if the JWT includes a JKU header, then the value in the header must match the URL provided at registration. I did not find that clear from the current phrasing.
column17: Sentence's meaning is unclear
column21: We can delete this confusing sentence from section 4, as it is addressed in section 5 as as well as 7.

column4: Backend Services Authorization> Registering a SMART Backend Service (communicating public keys):
column16: The spec says the client “SHALL register its client_ID” but later says the client “SHALL be assigned a client_id” – the first one is wrong. A client is assigned a client id.
column17: A client is assigned an identifier.
column21: Good catch! We should write "SHALL register its public key" (i.e., delete "its client_id" from this sentence).

column4: Backend Services Authorization> Authorization Server Obligations> Signature Verification
column16: It says the signature verification is in addition to the processing requirements in section 3 of RFC 7523, but verifying the signature is step 9 in that RFC, so this isn't really an addition.
column17: Signature verification is part of the processing requirements; not in addition to.
column21: Move "validate the signature on the JWT" to the the end of the introduction sentence -- i.e., we should say "The EHR’s authorization server SHALL validate the JWT according to the processing requirements defined in Section 3 of RFC7523, including validation of the signature on the JWT." Then we can delete the "validate the signature on the JWT" bullet from the list.

column4: Backend Services Authorization> Authorization Server Obligations> Signature Verification
column16: The IG should talk about caching. Should caching of the JWKS be allowed? There's the risk of an auth server accepting a key when it has been invalidated at the source location for a period of time, but if a client is especially active, it will avoid a lot of cross talk. I think this is something both parties MAY do, and the JWKS endpoint can use the cache-control response headers to provide a recommendation that it is comfortable with for cache lifetime. If no cache-control headers are provided, then the server must not cache the key set, and it may ignore the headers if present. Even if the position is ultimately no caching, I think this should be explicit in the document.
column17: How should JWK Set caching work?
column21: Caching is already mentioned - "The authorization server’s response MUST include the HTTP “Cache-Control” response header field with a value of “no-store,” as well as the “Pragma” response header field with a value of “no-cache.”

column4: Backend Services Authorization> Authorization Server Obligations> Issuing Access Tokens:
column16: In two places the spec says a lifetime of 300 seconds is recommended, however, in the very last sentence of this section it states that the token "MUST…[have] an expiration time of no more than five minutes". That contradicts an earlier statement which states the value “SHOULD_NOT exceed 300”
column17: Required access token lifetime is inconsistent in IG.
column21: Change: "MUST be short-lived, with an expiration time of no more than five minutes" to "MUST be short-lived, and SHOULD have an expiration time of no more than 300 seconds".

column4: Backend Services Authorization> Present an Access Token to FHIR API:
column16: The specification doesn’t provide guidance on what the error response should be if the access token fails validation or requests a resource that is outside of its scope. Presumably, if the access token is malformed/invalid, that’s a 401 per the RFC on bearer token usage and similarly if it requests only things for which it is not scoped. However, if it requests a mix of things, some of which it is scope for and some which it is not, the group should either decide whether the entire request should be rejected or if the resource server may choose to return the subset of requested resources for which the token is scoped.
column17: How should a bulk server respond to requests that include (some) resources outside of the client's scope?
column21: We lack experience to provide detailed prescriptive guidance on this question; similarly, we have not yet provided detailed guidance for behavior with the single-patient SMART API. In practice this issue is complex, since the wire protocol doesn't convey the full context and nuance of authorization decisions. For now, we recommend that servers return data that a client is authorized to see, rather than rejecting requests. This helps, for example, in cases where a client may be authorized to access only a subset of Observations (but our request language only allows the client to ask for all Observations or none).

column16: On the Export page, the export services under Bulk Data Kick-off Request had a single “$” prefix, but on these pages, the URLs have two “$$” – this may just be a notational convention I’, not familiar with, but the two are inconsistent
column17: Are two $$ intentional?
column21: Duplicate of #113. Block vote.

column16: I didn’t see anywhere noting which, if any, operations a resource service is required to support. If not all are required, is there any place a client app can go to learn which exports are available?
column17: How does discovery work?
column21:
All export operations are optional and servers should indicate support through entries in the server metadata (e.g., via CapabilityStatement.rest.operation).

We should add an extension to the CapabilityStatement.rest.resource.operation structure to convey a boolean value: `support-async`

column16: I think we should cover what security requirements are needed for the jku endpoint. I think it should not require authorization or authentication but should require HTTPS.
column17: IG should mandate that jku endpoint requires HTTPS, but not authnz.
column21: Agreed -- we should mandate https and no authn/authz.

column16: Should we modify the spec to account for CMS's additional file encryption and key exchange?
column17: Locking the room containing the safe
column21: We should add this as an optional approach to encrypting files. In the process we should ensure that JSON property names follow FHIR conventions (e.g., "keyMap" instead of "KeyMap"). If we do this we should update the sentence, "Work currently underway is exploring possible approaches for protecting extracted files persisted in the file server."

column14: HL7 FHIR Release 3, https://www.hl7.org/fhir/
column16: The top of the page specifies "based on FHIR R4", while this item refers to "HL7 FHIR Release 3". Is it a typo or as intended?
column17: Based on FHIR R4 title should be consistent with FHIR Release 3
column21: We should define the spec in terms of "FHIR R4 or later," but we note that support for these operations can be implemented on earlier FHIR versions.

column16: It's great that security considerations are included. In fact, it may be more of a challenge for FHIR bulk, since any sort of security attack, such as Denial of Service (DOS), might take down the service based on its special nature. Either clearly state the scope (this is not stated in Section 1) or provide future discussions. In Section 5.3, "429 Too Many Requests" is mentioned without a specification of how frequently is "a client if polling too frequently"; however, this mechanism itself may be flooded to deal with DOS attack, etc.
column17: Clarify the scope of security considerations especially in relation to DOS attacks
column21: Will need more information about how http://hl7.org/fhir/us/bulkdata/2019May/authorization/index.html#use-this-profile-when-the-following-conditions-apply fails to "clearly state the scope".

column14: 1.0.1 Use this profile
column17: Section number should be revised/removed in Use this profile
column21: The current heading is correct

column14: the client SHALL obtain a "client-to-client" digital certificate and …
column16: iIs it a "client-to-server" or "client-to-client" certificate?
column17: Clarify if it is a "client-to-server" or "client-to-client" certificate
column21: Duplicate of #31

column14: 5.0.1 Protocol details
column15: 5.1 Protocol details
column17: Section number should be revised/removed in Protocol details

column16: It's not clear if the System Level Export + _type=Practitioner parameter can allow for export of all Practitioners. Examples of such use cases would be useful for clarify (there is example for 5.1.5.1.1 Experimental Query Parameters, but nothing for 5.1.5 Query Parameters)
column17: Request for examples of a System Level Export using a specific _type parameter, as HealthcareService or Pracitioner
column21: Is the issue specifically about Practitioner? It's true we don't have an example, but the parameters apply to all defined operations.

column16: The actual ballot URL doesn't lead directly to the ballot content.  Recommend putting the content there, rather than expecting users to navigate to links in a PPT presentation and find their way to GitHub specification content.  As it stands, the ballot content seems to essentially be just https://github.com/smart-on-fhir/fhir-bulk-data-docs.
column17: Need to put actual ballot content into the ballot for github content
column21:
This commernter may not have successfully navigated from the HL7 Ballot Desktop; the Ballot Desktop included a link to http://hl7.org/fhir/us/bulkdata/2019May which includes full content -- or the commeter did not realize that the red menu bar at the top of the page was the navigation index for the ballot content.

We should add a section at the bottom of the index page reproducing key items from the menu at the top (Exports, Backend Services, Operations, History).

column16: As an HL7 standard, the HL7 Bulk Data specification (as opposed to the Argonaut project on this) should reference and use the HL7 US Core FHIR IG derived from the Argonaut IG
column17: Transition to US Core FHIR IG
column21:
We should update "Common Clinical Data Set" to say "US Core Data for Interoperability" and we should udpate:

"This use case exports all resources needed for the Common Clinical Data Set, as profiled by Argonaut. For a full list of these resources and profiles, see http://www.fhir.org/guides/argonaut/r2/profiles.html" to read:

"This use case exports all resources needed for the US Core Data for Interoperability. For a full list of these resources and profiles, see http://www.hl7.org/fhir/us/core/.

column16: Appreciate the security risk assessment (https://github.com/smart-on-fhir/fhir-bulk-data-docs/raw/9c5a9dcdfcd7b986f59a102bc2b4616552fed3e4/security-risk-assessment-report.pdf), and the approaches taken to address.  That's very helpful.
column17: Thanks for security risk assessment
column21: Thank you!

column16: To be more useful, the specification should enable defining for whom data are needed.  When will this be worked on?
column17: When will group specification be included in the spec?
column21: An API to define and manipulate Groups was out of scope for version 1. This may be future work for Bulk Data or may be taken up by a separate IG developer effort.

column16: Not sure it belongs in the spec, but consider providing guidance on further security precautions like notifying appropriate individuals/groups when a request is being processed.  E.g.: "text message and email --> note health system CIO and CMIO: there is currently an export of the entire EHR in progress by user X. Expected completion time is 6 hrs. Go to XYZ to over-ride request if not authorized."  Perhaps like an opt-in notification.  Maybe this happens outside of the spec, in individual implementations, but seems like it would alleviate concerns from data stewards if this type of notification capability was available.
column17: Consider a notification safeguard
column21: This is out of scope for Bulk Data v1, but server implementers may choose to follow a process like while remaining compatible with the spec.

column14: Implementers are encouraged to implement OAuth 2.0 access management in accordance with the SMART Backend Services: Authorization Guide.
column16: Hopefully I'm missing something here, but as stated just here (perhaps it's clarified elsewhere) it seems to be saying that the check is like a regular SMART on FHIR app, where a user who otherwise has access to the data can use his/her credentials to gain access.  In practice, individual clinical providers such as physicians are often given broad access to pretty much all patients (given the difficulty of telling whose patient records they will need to access beforehand). If this may be applicable, recommend specifying that such credentials can't be used.  I.e., that a rogue actor wouldn't be able to compromise one of thousands or tens of thousands of providers working at a health system (e.g., via a phishing attack pretending to be the IT help desk needing the user to reset their password) to do a bulk extract of all patient data using this mechanism.
column17: Can individual clinical provider credentials be used to initiate a bulk data export on all patients?
column21: The scopes defined for access are system-level scopes; typically these wouldn't be used by an individual clinician, and in any case the Backend Serviecs authorization guide leaves end-user authorization out of scope.

column14:
_since (FHIR instant type, optional)

Resources updated after this period will be included in the response
column16: Please provide clarification on what this means/how it is to be interpreted.  E.g., let's say there was a HbA1c lab test ordered 1/1/2001, the specimen was collected on 1/2/2001, and resulted on 1/3/2001. The health system implemented a FHIR STU2 server on 1/1/2018, and a STU3 server on 1/1/2019. Moreover, the bulk data comes not from the real-time database, but from the analytical database, which pulls it on demand.  I now request STU3 data on 4/26/2019, and request data "since" 6/1/2018.  Which of the above dates is going to be used?  Clinically, it should be 1/2/2001, as the specimen collection time is the clinically relevant time when looking at lab results.
column17: Clarify what date/time the _since flag uses.
column21:
The _since flag is designed to filter based on when FHIR Resource state has changed, rather than clinical eventing times. For servers pulling data in realtime from an external system, some evaluation would be required to determine when resource state had changed. We should address this when we reconcile $everything with $export, e.g. by adding "Resources updated after this period will be included in the response."

We might propose renaming to "_lastUpdated" to make this intent more clear. (Question for Grahame: any reason why $everything uses _since instead of _lastUpdated?)

column14: To request finer-grained filtering, a client MAY supply a _typeFilter parameter alongside the _type parameter. The value of the _typeFilter parameter is a comma-separated list of FHIR REST API queries that further restrict the results of the query. Understanding _typeFilter is OPTIONAL for FHIR servers; clients SHOULD be robust to servers that ignore _typeFilter.
column16: At least in the US, I think this potentially violates the HIPAA Minimum Necessary requirement (https://www.hhs.gov/hipaa/for-professionals/privacy/guidance/minimum-necessary-requirement/index.html).  E.g., let's say an external partners needs to get the patient's hemoglobin A1c lab tests for a diabetes population health management system.  And it sends in a query for the managed' patients' hemoglobin A1c results.  But instead the health system/EHR, due to not recognizing/supporting these filters, sends them ALL observations about the patient, including for example the fact that the patient is positive for HIV.  I think that could potentially be in violation.  Which may mean that this bulk data export approach can only initially be used safely for when the entire record needs to be exported. Related to this: because OAuth scope tokens are very coarse-grained (e.g., Observation/read rather than Observation/read/[what the client actually needs access to], it seems in this case the external partner couldn't be restricted to only pulling A1cs by OAuth, which seems to be a separate issue. Would recommend at a minimum including a discussion on this topic, that it needs to be considered by users of the specification.
column17: Does the inability to filter data potentially violate HIPAA's Minimum Necessary requirement?
column21: While we wouldn't address HIPAA directly in the context of this interational specification, it would be useful to add a note that "servers MAY limit the data returned to a specific client in accordance with local considerations (e.g., policies or regulations)." This would be similar to the EHR only returning patients that a user has access to when responding to an open-ended search.

column14:
Example Request with _typeFilter

The following is an export request for MedicationRequest resources and Condition resources, where the client would further like to restrict MedicationRequests to requests that are active, or else completed after July 1 2018. This can be accomplished with two subqueries, joined together with a comma for a logical "or":

    MedicationRequest?status=active
    MedicationRequest?status=completed&date=gt2018-07-01T00:00:00Z
column16: How do you specify the FHIR version to be used?  E.g., if MedicationRequest is supported in both STU3 and R4, how do you specify you want STU3 rather than R4?  This should be specified.  E.g., is it based on the FHIR server endpoint?  But what if a FHIR server supports multiple endpoints, or some resources are only supported in one FHIR version? (e.g., most of what we want is supported via R4, but some resources are still only avaialble in STU3, and you want all of the relevant data)
column17: How do you specify the FHIR version to be used?
column21: Clients should follow the regular pattern for determining a server's version as described at http://build.fhir.org/versioning.html#cs-version. We don't see special considerations for Bulk Data.

column14:
Bulk Data Delete Request

After a bulk data request has been started, a client MAY send a delete request to the URI provided in the Content-Location header to cancel the request.
column16: This may be something that happens out-of-spec/out-of-standard, but should someone other than the rquestor be provided a standard way to kill the request?  E.g., clients put in big requests (e.g., full data copy-downs), and they bring the source system (EHR or perhaps the undelrying data warehouse) to a crawl.  How is one expected to kill this if it's not the client but more the system manager?  Perhaps if it's just a few big queries it's easy to identify and kill, but if it's something like multi-threaded smaller queries, this could be hard to kill unless that's done at the data requesting module level.
column17: Should someone other than the requestor be provided a standard way to kill the request?
column21: This is an interesting question that we should address in a future version of the specification.

column14: In the Securrity Considerations link to SMART Backend Services: Authorization Guide, system scopes have the format system/(:resourceType|*).(read|write|*)

column21: Granular permissions management is challenging, and has not been the focus of this project; we've been focused on describing the interaction pattern. We exepct that servers may implement additional controls and filters that are applied to a given client (e.g., based on information like IRB permissions that can ben communicated at registration time).

column16: Consider using the resouce "Parameters" as the body of the operation instead. This would allow filter parameters to be added to the body of the operation request, rather than in the query string. It may get complicated having to properly encode and decode the query string parameters for filters that are more complex. If the Parameters resource is used instead, these more-complex filter parameters can be embedded in the body of the request and encoding is not as much of a concern. You could even add extensions to Parameters.parameter to indicate what type of filter to apply (whether it is a FHIR Search filter, or a CQL filter, or a GraphDefinition). Generally, there is much more flexibility with the Parameters resource than there is with having these filters be in the query string.
column17: Use Parameters resource for the body of the request
column21: The current expressivity of the bulk data export is limited, and works well with simple query parameters. In the future if we introduce more complex filters, we may want to specify how the operation can be invoked with POST + Parameters.

column16: Consider allowing an option/parameter in the operation where the caller can indicate a RESTful endpoint (hook) to provide status updates, and maybe even an additional RESTful endpoint for where to send the export when it is done. This could potentially reduce the logic needed for integration where the requestor of the $export would not need to poll the server, the server could notify the requestor with a sort of PUSH notification.
column17: Support for REST-HOOK endpoints in the $export request
column21: This would be a valuable notification capability, but it goes beyond our scope for v1. There is ongoing work to refine FHIR subscriptions, particularly with relation to subscribing to operation-lifecycle-related events.

column16: Provide more descriptions for each of the responses. Provide a full example of the $export request, it's response, and the various polling responses. Also consider creating a table in 5.3.1 that shows the "status" and the "http status code" side-by-side... That would be a good reference to have. Ex" 202 = "In-Progress", 5XX = "Error", 200 = "Complete"

column21: We currently have three response types, and a documented response status for each. We'll discuss whether reformatting as a table would increase readability.

column16: I don't suggest requiring "new-line delimited json". These exports will surely become very large. Pretty-printed JSON tends to take up a significant amount more bytes than the equivilent minified version of the JSON. I think ndjson should be an option, but not required. Only application/fhir+json should be required, while application/fhir+ndjson should be an option.
column17: Change the required response/file/download format
column21: For this commenter, we wnat to clarify that ndjson is a required format (though clients and servers may choose to agree on on ther formats). Also note that ndjson is not a form of "pretty printing"; it's generall a compressed (minified) format. We should not change the specification ; though the clarification we add for for #77 will likely clarify this commentor's confusion

column16: Suggest adding a parameter that indicates what the maximum size of a Bundle chunk should be. For exports that produce a download of greater than 10mb (or however much), the requestor may want the Bundle split up into smaller chunks. For example, I would like to be able to ask for an export that is split into 10mb Bundles. Or maybe instead split based on number of resources per Bundle (ex: 100 resources per Bundle)... The result would be a zip/archive of multiple Bundle files.
column17: Allow spliting response into smaller chunks/bundles

column21: This is a good suggestion but may be a better addition for a future version

This functional requirement is nearly met with the current spec: a server can accept a request but defer processing, per Section 5.3, providing a a retry-after header indicating that results won't be available until after peak hours. There is no need to force the client to re-issue its request.

column14: Providers and organizations accountable for managing the health of populations often need to efficiently access large volumes of information on a group of individuals. For example, a health system may want to periodically retrieve updated clinical data from an EHR to a research database, a provider may want to send clinical data on a roster of patients to their ACO to calculate quality measures, or an EHR may want to access claims data to close gaps in care. In most cases, access to these bulk-data exports is pre-authorized between the data holder and the data requester.[...]These draft specifications outline a standardized, FHIR based approach for exporting bulk data from a FHIR server to a pre-authorized client.
column16:
The Bulk Data Access IG (BDA IG) skirts critical authorization issues with its use cases by making authorization a precondition out of scope of this specification.  Authorization of requesters changes dynamically, and must be checked prior to each disclosure. 

The first use case: "a health system may want to periodically retrieve updated clinical data from an EHR to a research database"
Unless this is the type of "research" permitted under HIPAA operations then the health system would need to check whether each patient has authorized/not revoked disclosure to the research database as required by HIPAA, and that the patient has signed an informed consent/not revoked informed consent to participate in research, except where an IRB has waived the need for informed consent.  These changes can happen at any moment so "pre-authorization" of clients puts a server custodian at risk for breach.  Similarly, a provider can only disclose patient information for purposes of operations to their ACO for patients that have or have had a relationship with the payer entities in the ACO.  For those patients who have a relationship with the ACO payer entities, the provider needs to check that each such patient has not exercised a HIPAA right to restrict disclosure to payers for services paid in full out of pocket.  Again, such changes can happen at any moment so "pre-authorization" of clients puts a server custodian at risk for breach.  

To mitigate the risk of breach and provide patients the assurances they need to trust that Bulk Data Access will be done in accordance with Applicable Laws and their consent directives, we recommend that the Bulk Data Access IG change the `_typeFilter` parameter goes from optional to mandatory. If this parameter is not implemented there won’t be any guaranteed mechanism to filter out sensitive data or ensure that Bulk Data Access server custodians comply with HIPAA purposes of use limitations on disclosures permitted without authorization.  For detailed technical specifications on how this can be achieved, please see Privacy Aware Bulk Data Access @ https://confluence.hl7.org/pages/createpage.action?spaceKey=SEC&fromPageId=42995037
column17: Add fine grained requests and permissions for the _typeFilter
column21: While we are agree with the value of fine-granted requests and permissions, we have insufficient implementation experience working with typeFilter  We also note that many authorization decisions may be out of band, a given server imposes restrictions based on its own policies, e.g. based on information obtained or representations made at client registration time.

Agree, we will discuss combining renaming $export to $everything. Challenges may include alignment of parameter names and any adjustment we want to make to the existing $everything definition that is in R4.

column14: This implementation guide is intended to be used by developers of backend services (clients) and FHIR Resource Servers (e.g., EHR systems, data warehouses, and other clinical and administrative systems) that aim to interoperate by sharing large FHIR datasets. The guide defines the application programming interfaces (APIs) through which an authenticated and authorized client may request a bulk-data export from a server, receive status information regarding progress in the generation of the requested files, and receive these files. It also includes recommendations regarding the FHIR resources that might be exposed throuh the export interface.
column15: This implementation guide is intended to be used by developers of backend services (clients) and FHIR Resource Servers (e.g., EHR systems, data warehouses, and other clinical and administrative systems) that aim to interoperate by sharing large FHIR datasets. The guide defines the application programming interfaces (APIs) through which an authenticated and authorized client may request a bulk-data export from a server, receive status information regarding progress in the generation of the requested files, and receive these files. It also includes recommendations regarding the FHIR resources that might be exposed through the export interface.
